H0.text: Decreases in powerful hurricanes are most likely to cause changes to estuary habitats on a global scale, where estuaries are marine environments formed by the flow of freshwater from rivers into the ocean and support highly productive ecosystems inhabited by birds, fish, turtles, and many other organisms.

H1.text: Decreases in volcanic eruptions are most likely to cause changes to estuary habitats on a global scale, as estuaries are marine environments where freshwater from rivers flows into the ocean and support diverse organisms such as birds, fish, turtles, and many others.

H2.text: Increases in earthquakes are most likely to cause changes to estuary habitats on a global scale, where estuaries are marine environments located in areas where fresh water from rivers flows into the ocean, are among the most biologically productive ecosystems, and are inhabited by birds, fish, turtles, and many other organisms.

H3.text: Increases in sea level are most likely to cause changes to estuary habitats on a global scale, where estuaries are marine environments located in areas where freshwater from rivers flows into the ocean, are among the most biologically productive ecosystems, and are inhabited by birds, fish, turtles, and many other organisms.

A4.text: Both mangroves and tidal marshes protect against storm surges, waves and tsunamis, so their loss makes the effects of sea level rise worse.

A5.text: Flooding and soil/water salinization threaten the habitats of coastal plants, birds, and freshwater/estuarine fish when seawater reaches inland.
